Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Genetic and biological substrates facilitating detection and evaluation of potential mates in a novel mammalian model
Award.AbstractNarration: This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Locating, identifying, and selecting suitable mates is a fundamental challenge common to all life. These important aspects of reproduction are often accomplished through chemical communication involving pheromones. Thus, the chemical sense of smell used to detect pheromones is important to successful animal reproduction. African giant pouched rats possess a powerful sense of smell which allows them to communicate using a complex system of pheromone signals. These pheromones are used to pass detailed information to one another about gender, age, reproductive features and quality as potential mates. Despite the importance, little is known about how this information is passed using pheromones or what physical mechanisms are used to detect and interpret these signals. This research seeks to answer these questions and represents the first steps toward establishing a unique rodent model of reproduction and chemical communication that will advance the understanding of how appropriate mates are identified. The fellow will broaden participation within the scientific community by including undergraduate student researchers at the beginning of their careers and through collaborative international field research involving students and researchers from Sokoine University of Agriculture in Morogoro, Tanzania.<br/><br/>Utilizing an integrative approach combining behavioral, physiological and molecular evidence, this research seeks to describe the genetic and biological substrates facilitating detection, identification and evaluation of potential mates in the African giant pouched rat. First, the genetic potential for expression of vomeronasal chemical receptor proteins will be investigated using in-silico genomic analyses comparing receptor repertoires of related species to identify biologically relevant genes and provide insight regarding the relative biological importance of the vomeronasal chemosensory system of the pouched rat. Next, high throughout RNA-sequencing will be used to examine expression of vomeronasal and olfactory chemical receptors and describe variation by gender, developmental phenotype, or reproductive status suggestive of optimization of sensitivity toward biologically relevant chemical stimuli. This research component will be conducted in collaboration with Sokoine University of Agriculture using animals from natural Tanzanian populations. Lastly, behavioral assays will determine the specific roles of the vomeronasal and main olfactory chemosensory systems, and how these systems interact to facilitate chemical communication and reproduction. Mentoring students and collaboration with scientists in Tanzania will broaden the impact of this work.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
African giant pouched rats are large, intelligent rodents best known for the ability to detect human-made explosives by scent. The rationale behind this project was to study the mechanisms underlying the pouched rat’s unusually acute sense of smell in order to learn more about the biology, physiology, and behavior of this unique and interesting species.

We investigated these mechanisms from a molecular perspective to study the genes involved in the process of detecting and interpreting olfactory information, as well as investigating the identity of some important signaling molecules used in pouched rat social communication.

As this project progressed, we because increasingly interested in the mechanisms underlying the acquisition of chemical signals by the olfactory sensory system, as well as the processing and interpretation of those signals in the brain. Clearly, this species’ sense of smell is much more acute than other species, even those such as canines, that are commonly used as ‘biodetectors’.

As a large step toward these objectives, we produced the first high-quality, annotated genome sequence of the pouched rat. This genomic reference sequence contains a wealth of genetic information about this species on which a substantial amount current research has been based, and which will enable future research for years to come.

We compared the genetic content of the pouched rat’s genome to that of several related rodents to discover what was unique about the pouched rat. We found that the evolutionary history of the pouched rat has indeed favored the evolution of powerful olfactory capabilities, which has manifested in a striking increase in the number of genes involved in the detection and interpretation of chemical signals. We found that the pouched rat has about 2,000 individual genes encoding olfactory receptor proteins – the physical structures that bind chemical signals in the environment to initiate the sending of olfactory information to the brain. This huge number of olfactory receptors is approximately equal to, or maybe even exceeding, that found in any other animal to date.

A major question that has puzzled researchers for years is “How did pouched rats develop such a sensitive ability to detect the scent of explosives?” Given that explosives did not exist throughout evolutionary history, there could have been no advantage to their ability to detect them. Thus, this ability must necessarily have evolved for a different purpose. To address this question, we investigated the actual chemical compounds in pouched rat urine, which is a major route this species uses to communicate.

Astonishingly, we found that the chemical structures of compounds used as vital social signals are often similar, or even identical, to those compounds found in human-made explosives. Therefore, we find it very likely that an evolutionary emphasis on social signaling has inadvertently led to the pouched rat’s olfactory sensitivity to explosive compounds.

Over the last two years, we have collected a large amount of gene expression data which is still the focus of several ongoing analyses expected to yield a great amount of useful information regarding the chemical senses and social signaling mechanisms used by pouched rats.

This project has, so far, yielded 3 presentations at scientific conferences and 1 published paper and 2 manuscripts in preparation, as well as a wealth of additional data we expect will lead to 2-4 additional publications in the near future. The work conducted as part of this project afforded the opportunity to train and include 9 undergraduates in research, and resulted in several major fruitful collaborations between research teams at multiple universities. Overall, this project has led to major advances in our understanding of the biological and evolutionary mechanisms underlying chemical communication and olfactory information processing in the pouched rat, and it has generated many new testable hypotheses that will inform and improve the methods by which this species is used as a biodetector of explosives.
